Select Columns with Concentrated Probability Mass or Maximum Non-Uniformity

Source: R/method.R
iskept.Rd

Identifies columns in a probability matrix that have their mass concentrated in few entries (reaching a cumulative threshold quickly when sorted). If no columns meet this concentration criterion, selects the single column that deviates most from uniformity.

Usage

iskept(X, eps = 1e-09)

Arguments

X

A numeric matrix with dimensions p × L, where:

  • Each column represents a probability vector

  • Each column should sum to 1 (or approximately 1 due to floating-point precision)

  • Columns with negative values or sums significantly different from 1 may produce unexpected results

eps

Level of precision

Value

A logical vector of length L where:

  • TRUE indicates a column is selected ("kept")

  • FALSE indicates a column is not selected

  • Column names from X are preserved in the result

  • At least one element will always be TRUE

Details

This function implements a two-step column selection process:

Step 1: Concentration-based selection For each column in matrix X:

  • Values are sorted in descending order

  • The cumulative sum is computed

  • If the cumulative sum exceeds threshold thr before using all entries, the column is considered "concentrated" and marked TRUE

  • This identifies columns where a small subset of entries contain most of the probability mass

Step 2: Uniformity-based fallback If no column meets the concentration criterion:

  • Computes the squared Euclidean distance from each column to the uniform vector (1/p, ..., 1/p)

  • Selects only the column with the maximum distance from uniformity

  • This guarantees at least one column is always selected

Note

  • The function works best when input columns are valid probability vectors (non-negative, sum to 1)

  • For edge cases where multiple columns tie for maximum distance from uniformity, only one is selected

  • Computational complexity scales linearly with the number of columns
